newsitem.title: USA: US West Coast prods flat to up on APIs, refineries.
newsitem.headline: US West Coast prods flat to up on APIs, refineries.

text.p: U.S. West Coast product prices were steady to higher in moderate late trade, getting a lift from refinery buying and drops in inventories.
Gasoline inventories in West Coast PADD 5 fell 709,000 barrels to 26.9 million last week, according to data from the American Petroleum Institute (API) released late Tuesday.
"That's an extremely low number for out here," one trader claimed. Fundamentally, supplies appeared under pressure as key Los Angeles refiners bought to compensate for lost capacity.
Mobil, Chevron, and Arco were undergoing or planning repairs on major units, traders said.
And Ultramar's roughly 70,000 barrel-per-day plant in L.A., was said to be short diesel due to a hydrotreater which was shut last week.
Conventional or "clear" grade gasoline in Los Angeles was seen between 69.50 and 70 cents for September parcels, steady with earlier prices.
And Premium September conventional in L.A. stayed 10 cents over regular. Premiums were higher because of the outage at Mobil's Torrance, Calif., reformer, which upgrades gasolines.
Ultra-clean CARB gasoline rose 0.50 cent to 71.50/72.50 cents for September parcels.
Most trade shifted to October parcels, traders said, noting October barrels were lower by a half to full cent.

One broker said the market watched for the return of Powerine, a small refinery in California, that could return to production by month's end. He said that rumours indicated the plant would manufacture feedstocks.

Meanwhile, low sulphur diesel in L.A. edged up half a cent to 71.50/72.50 cents a gallon, while CARB grade was unchanged in late trading. San Francisco gasolines were assessed two cents lower than L.A. material.
